head: Head

once_verified_press_the_download_button: Once verified, press the download button
for_the_mosquito_alert_complete_dataset_: For the Mosquito Alert complete dataset, with advanced options, go to Mosquito Alert portal:
this_view_does_not_exist: This map view does not exist
report_with_the_observations_displayed_i: Report with the observations displayed in the current map view (maximum: 300 observations)
verify_this_by_looking_at_the_map_point_: Verify this by looking at the map point counter (on the top right map corner).
data_on_mosquitoes_breeding_places_and_b: data on mosquitoes, breeding places and bites
sent_by_citizens_through_the_mosquito_al: sent by citizens, through the Mosquito Alert app.
part_of_this_data_has_been_validated_by_: Part of this data has been validated by entomology professionals or by Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms. You will also find data modeled from the original observations
if_you_want_the_complete_mosquito_alert_: For the Mosquito Alert complete dataset, with advanced options, go to Mosquito Alert portal:
you_can_also_consult_the_Mosquito_Alert_: You can also consult the Mosquito Alert website:
model_maps_provide_information_to_help_b: Model maps provide information to help better understand the places and times at which people are more likely to encounter one of the target mosquito species or to be bitten by a mosquito. The models estimate the probability of at least one valid report being sent through Mosquito Alert from each area during a given month. These estimates are based on statistical models that account for a number of different environmental and social variables, including weather, land cover, and participants’ sampling effort. This last variable is important because we want to know whether low reporting from a given place reflects low numbers of the given target species’ or simply low numbers of citizen scientists participating at that point. Model estimates are made holding sampling effort constant, meaning that we are estimating the probability we would expect to see if Mosquito Alert participants were all putting the same effort into searching for and reporting target species at all times and places. We limit estimates of the target mosquito species to those areas in which the species has already been confirmed as present by the ECDC and/or Mosquito Alert (see the distribution maps).
these_estimates_are_generated_monthly_fo: These estimates are generated monthly for each of the smallest administrative units on the map (in most countries these are municipalities). The estimates for each new month are available a few days after that month ends. When you zoom out from the smallest administrative units, the map aggregates them into larger units. Relative uncertainty of the estimates is shown based on the size of the circles drawn on top of the map, but these circles can be made more transparent or switched off if they get in the way. You can also choose the color palette that you like best.
the_map_currently_shows_estimates_for_al: The map currently shows estimates for all countries that are part of the European Environmental Agency because this is where we have the most data so far, but Mosquito Alert is increasingly being used in many other parts of the world and the model estimates will soon be expanded to include these as well. More information, as well as access to the estimates themselves, can be found at:
model_maps_show_the_probability_of_encou: Model maps show the probability of encountering a specific mosquito species or of receiving a mosquito bite. Probabilities are based on data submitted by citizens to Mosquito Alert. The first estimates for a month are based on observations received for that month in previous years, estimates that are updated weekly with data for the current year to readjust the values in real time.
models_show_the_probability_of_encounter: Models show the probability of encountering each of the target species: the tiger mosquito, the yellow fever mosquito, the Asian bush mosquito, the Korean mosquito, and the common house mosquito. Another model shows the probability of receiving a mosquito bite, which does not correspond to any specific mosquito species, but to all the reports of bites received, reflecting the human-mosquito interaction in the area.
estimates_are_displayed_at_different_wor: Estimates are displayed at different world’s administrative areas or boundaries depending on the zoom and the map view. Administrative areas in the database are countries and lower lever subdivisions such as provinces. At high resolution, estimates are displayed in grids of approximately 2x2 kilometers (grid of 0.05 degrees latitude by 0.05 degrees longitude). In addition to the probability of encountering a mosquito or receiving a bite, each administrative area also shows its uncertainty value.
this_calculation_considers_the_sampling_: This calculation considers the sampling effort, considering the number of participants with the active app in each grid or area in the defined time. The probability of mosquitoes or of receiving a mosquito bite is higher in a grid in which 10 observations have been received and there are 5 participants, than in another with 10 observations and 10 participants. Modeling observations and active participants determines the value of the probability shown on the map.
this_probability_has_been_observed_to_co: This probability has been observed to correspond to the observations of the tiger mosquito obtained by traditional surveillance methods (ovitraps), thus demonstrating that it is a good way of estimating the presence and abundance of a species.
la_web_de_mosquito_alert_utiliza_cookies: The Mosquito Alert website uses its own and third-party cookies for technical and analytical purposes. To manage them, use the manager. If you want more information, access the Cookies Policy.
escoge_que_tipos_de_galletas_aceptas_que: Choose what types of cookies you accept that Mosquito Alert can store in your browser.
las_galletas_o_cookies_son_pequenos_arch: Cookies are small text files that are installed on the computers from which our website is accessed. Among other purposes, cookies record the preferences and browsing habits of a user.
se_asocian_al_usuario_y_a_su_equipo_pero: They are associated with the user and his team, but do not provide directly identifying data. Some cookies, for example those that allow statistics or advertisements to be compiled, require the consent of the user of our website. On the other hand, other cookies, those of a technical nature or those necessary to offer a service requested by the user, are essential for the operation of the site.
las_cookies_se_pueden_clasificar_segun_s: Cookies can be classified according to their validity, who manages them or their purpose.
de_sesion_son_temporales_y_quedan_en_el_: Session cookies: they are temporary and remain in your browser's cookie file until you leave the website
persistentes_quedan_almacenadas_y_el_sit: Persistent cookies: they are stored and the website reads them every time you visit
propias_son_las_propias_del_titular_del_: First-party cookies: are those of the owner of the website from which the services are provided to the user
de_terceros_se_envian_al_usuario_por_par: Third-party cookies: they are sent to the user by a third party, different from the owner of the place
necesarias_las_imprescindibles_para_faci: Necessary cookies: the essentials to facilitate your connection. There is no option to disable them, since they are necessary for the operation of the website
tecnicas_las_que_permiten_controlar_el_t: Technical cookies: those that allow data traffic and communication to be controlled, session identification and access to restricted access pages, among others.
analiticas_proporcionan_informacion_esta: Analytical cookies: provide statistical information and allow us to improve services
en_la_web_de_mosquito_alert_utilizamos_u: On the Mosquito Alert website we use three necessary cookies and Google Analytics cookies
las_cookies_de_google_analytics_permiten: Google Analytics cookies allow statistical analysis of the information accessed by users of our site. The data collected may include the activity of the user's browser when visiting us, the route that users take to our site, information from the visitor's Internet service provider, the number of times users access the site and the behavior of visitors. users on our site (pages you have visited, forms that have been completed and the like)
puedes_obtener_mas_informacion_sobre_goo: You can get more information about Google Analytics at
para_controlar_la_recopilacion_de_datos_: To control the collection of data for analytical purposes by Google Analytics, you can go to
a_continuacion_mostramos_una_tabla_con_l: Below we show a table with the cookies used. For each cookie we include the following attributes: purpose, provider, cookie name, management, validity and function
permite_recordar_las_cookies_aceptadas_c: Allows you to remember previously accepted cookies compliance
mostrar_la_ventana_informativa_solo_en_l: how info window only on first visit
registra_una_identificacion_unica_que_se: Registers a unique identification that is used to generate statistical data on how the visitor uses the website
las_imprescindibles_para_facilitar_vuest: the essentials to facilitate your connection. There is no option to disable them, since they are necessary for the operation of the website
las_que_permiten_controlar_el_trafico_y_: those that allow data traffic and communication to be controlled, session identification and access to restricted access pages, among others.
proporcionan_informacion_estadistica_y_p: provide statistical information and allow us to improve services
el_mapa_contiene_informacion_de_5_especi: The map contains information on 5 species of mosquito that can transmit diverse infectious pathogens:
ademas_puedes_visualizar_posibles_lugare: In addition, you can visualize possible breeding sites for these insects on public roads. This information is complemented with probability models, elaborated from citizen data and with the effort of sampling or distribution of participants.
segun_los_expertos_o_los_algoritmos_de_i: according to experts or AI algorithms, the photos of this observation could be from Tiger mosquito
en_estos_casos_no_es_posible_determinar_: in these cases, it is not possible to determine with certainty which species it is.
segun_los_expertos_o_los_algoritmos_de_i: : according to experts or Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms, the photos of this observation could be of a yellow fever mosquito
: according to experts or AI algorithms, the photos of this observation could be from the Asian bush mosquito
tambien_incluye_observaciones_que_podria: It also includes observations that could be either
segun_los_expertos_o_los_algoritmos_de_i: according to experts or AI algorithms, the photos of this observation could be from the Korean mosquito
: according to experts or AI algorithms, the photos of this observation could be of the common house mosquito

according to experts or AI algorithms, these observations and their photos do not allow to determine any specific mosquito species. It also includes observations sent as “mosquito” that have not been evaluated as they do not contain associated images.
observaciones_ciudadanas_de_picaduras_de: Citizen observations of mosquito bites, of any species and without any type of validation by experts or AI algorithms.
observaciones_ciudadanas_de_posibles_lug: : citizen observations of possible mosquito breeding sites (identified by citizens as "stormdrain with water"), mostly without any kind of validation by experts or AI algorithms.
citizen observations of possible mosquito breeding sites (identified by citizens as “storm drain without water"), mostly without any kind of validation by experts or AI algorithms.
: citizen observations of possible mosquito breeding sites (identified by citizens as “other types of breeding sites”), mostly without any kind of validation by experts or AI algorithms.
segun_los_expertos_o_los_algoritmos_de_i: according to experts or AI algorithms, the photos of this observation could be of other species of mosquito
la_capa_muestra_la_distribucion_de_los_p: The layer shows the distribution of participants, with darker grids indicating a greater number of devices with the app installed or that have been in the area for a long time. This data is essential to be able to develop models: without this information it would not be possible to know if there are many mosquitoes in an area or if there is a lot of participation. In ecology, this information is known as sampling effort, allowing observations to be corrected to make them comparable between areas.
selecciona_las_capas_de_informacion_que_: Select the layers of information that you are interested in viewing: mosquito observations, bites, breeding sites, other species and sampling effort.
filtra_tu_seleccion_de_distintas_maneras: Filter your selection in different ways:
escribe_y_selecciona_del_desplegable_tu_: Write and select your place of interest from the dropdown.
puedes_usar_mas_de_una_etiqueta_se_mostr: You can use more than one tag. Observations that contain at least one of the labels used will be displayed.
escribe_el_identificador_corto_de_un_inf: : Type the short identifier of a report in the hashtag search engine preceded by the symbol:
ejemplo_6ruid_puedes_usar_mas_de_un_iden: Example > :6RUID. You can use more than one identifier. Observations that contain at least one of the identifiers used will be displayed.
por_fecha_o_rango_de_fechas: BY DATE OR RANGE OF DATES:
los_filtros_aplican_a_todas_las_capas_de: The filters apply to all the information layers of the observations (mosquitoes, breeding sites, bites, other species). The "sampling effort" layer can only be filtered by date or date range.
los_filtros_son_acumulativos_es_decir_qu: The filters are cumulative: they act on the previously selected range of data. For example, if we filter mosquitoes from the city of Barcelona, and then search for a hashtag, the map will return only those observations from the city of Barcelona that have that hashtag.
descarga_los_datos_seleccionados_en_la_v: Download the selected data in your map view and generate html reports with the selected data in your map view.
consulta_la_informacion_de_la_vista_del_: View map view information in a time series graph format.
comparte_la_vista_del_mapa_consulta_la_a: Share the map view, get help and map information, and change the map language.
consulta_el_grado_de_probabilidad_e_ince: Check the probability and uncertainty of encountering a specific mosquito species. Select the species and the time range.
confirm_logout_message: Are you sure you want to Logout?
model_not_found_on_server: This models was not found on the server
this_map_view_does_not_exist: This map view does not exist
if_you_are_using_safari_please_check_tha: If you are using Safari, please Check that your pop-up windows block is not blocking the list of observations
this_interactive_map_has_been_funded_by: This interactive map has been funded by
the_distribution_maps_provide_informatio: The distribution maps provide information about the distribution of mosquito species studied by Mosquito Alert in the European Union and neighboring countries. The current distribution is derived from a blend of data sources, including the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), other authoritative channels, and the citizen science reports collected by Mosquito Alert. The ECDC’s information is nourished by both published and unpublished data provided and validated by experts. Meanwhile, Mosquito Alert data are classified and validated by experts from images provided by citizens through the app.
for_invasive_species_the_possible_distri: For invasive species, the possible distribution statues represented are:
red_represent_areas_where_a_mosquito_pop: Red: Represent areas where a mosquito population is considered established, meaning there’s evidence of reproduction, overwintering, or a persistent presence over time, within at least one municipality in the administrative unit.
light_yellow_signifies_that_the_species_: Light Yellow: Signifies that the species has been detected within the past 5 years according to ECDC data, suggesting an introduction of the species. However, the establishment of this species has yet to be confirmed.
dark_yellow_depicts_areas_where_both_the: Dark Yellow: Depicts areas where both the ECDC and Mosquito Alert have indicated the introduction of the species.
dark_blue_indicates_regions_where_mosqui: Dark Blue: Indicates regions where Mosquito Alert has reported the introduction of the species in places where the ECDC lacks data or considers the species absent. Introductions here implies possible sightings reported by citizens in the last 5 years.
light_blue_mark_regions_where_mosquito_a: Light Blue: Mark regions where Mosquito Alert reports of the species have been recorded this current year. It highlights the yearly contributions of citizen science in areas where neither the ECDC nor other official sources have reported the introduction or establishment of the species.
these_maps_illustrate_the_geographical_s: These maps illustrate the geographical spread of mosquito vectors across varying administrative units, determined by the data source. The ECDC data is represented at a NUTs3 equivalent administrative level, except for Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom, where NUTs2 equivalent is applied. In Spain, the distribution of invasive species is displayed at the municipal level, based on information from regional administrations provided to the CCAES (Center for Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies) and examined by a panel of experts.
it_is_crucial_to_note_that_these_maps_do: It is crucial to note that these maps do not signify the definitive stance or position of the respective countries.
discoveries_description:
The Mosquito Alert Discovery Map is a dynamic tool that showcases the power of citizen science in detecting mosquito species across Europe and beyond. By visualizing observations submitted through the Mosquito Alert platform, the map offers timely insights that complement official surveillance efforts and contribute to the early detection of mosquito-borne disease risks.

In Europe, the map uses official data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) at the NUTS3 level as a reference framework. In Spain, municipal-level data from the Center for Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies (CCAES) serves as the benchmark for this analysis. These authoritative sources provide a foundation against which citizen-reported discoveries can be compared.

The map’s legend clearly distinguishes between two types of data: yellow areas (indicate regions with officially recognized mosquito presence) and red areas (highlight locations where Mosquito Alert participants have reported mosquito species that are not yet reflected in official records).

By spotlighting these community-driven discoveries, the map reveals potential gaps in surveillance and underscores the value of real-time, ground-level data. It empowers citizens, researchers, and public health officials to work together in identifying emerging risks, informing response strategies, and refining monitoring systems.

The Mosquito Alert Discovery Map exemplifies how open, participatory science can enhance public health infrastructure and foster a shared responsibility in managing vector-borne disease threats.
